H0.text: Combustion is the law Lavoisier proposed in the late 1700s after conducting experiments in which a substance burned and the weight of the container and its contents remained unchanged before and after the experiment.

H1.text: Fixed proportions is the law that Antoine Lavoisier proposed in the late 1700s after observing that the weight of a container and its contents remained unchanged when a substance burned.

H2.text: Conservation of mass is the law that Antoine Lavoisier proposed in the late 1700s after observing that the weight of a container and its contents remained unchanged when a substance burned.

H3.text: Conservation of energy is the law that Antoine Lavoisier proposed after observing that the weight of a container and its contents remained unchanged before and after a substance burned in his late‑1700s experiments.

A4.text: Careful experiments were performed in which chemical reactions.BindingSource such as rusting were allowed to take place in sealed glass ampoules; it was found that the chemical reaction did not change the weight of the sealed container and its contents.

A5.text: A more refined series of experiments were later carried out by Antoine Lavoisier who expressed his conclusion in 1773 and popularized the principle of conservation of mass.
